body:
Thanks for the writeup, @a-h!

I think the main advantages to being able to install binaries are being able to install closed source software, and having the build flags/etc in a single place (in our particular case, `.goreleaser.yml`).

So, that's why I initially wanted to go that way... we might make it optional to our users, though.

That being said, to make this work, goreleaser would basically need to create a nix file in a given github repository, and that's it? Is there any specific filenames to be aware of?

It might be another pipe similar to brew, krew, etc...

No problem!

Yes, I think the job is to maintain a `flake.nix` in a repo using a pipeline, and tag it with releases. That's what `xc` does.

It uses a Go template to populate the `xc.nix` file that's then referenced by the `flake.nix`: 

* Template to update the `xc.nix`:
  * https://github.com/joerdav/xc/blob/main/xc.nix.tmpl
* Script to update the `xc.nix`
  * https://github.com/joerdav/xc/blob/main/update-nix.sh
* Flake that uses the `xc.nix` defition
  * https://github.com/joerdav/xc/blob/main/flake.nix

awesome, so, I guess the next step is to define our template for it... and for that I'll need to learn some stuff :D 

BTW: if you have a path suggestion to learn all this let me know, otherwise I'll just jump into the documentation hehe

fwiw, spent most of this weekend playing with nix, home-manager, etc... 

Does anyone have any thoughts on distributing from the pre-compiled binaries as @a-h provided?
